results.title: Noddy gets into trouble (K)
results.creator_credit: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. Noddy feels he is starting an “extra special” day and then finds he is suspected of theft of cakes and tarts because his cap bell was heard at the scene. The townspeople shun him as further thefts occur, but in the end, with the help of Big Ears and Little Ears, Noddy captures the real thief and presents him to Mr Plodd the Policeman. Narrated by Richard Briers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions

results.title: Noddy be brave (K)
results.creator_credit: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. Noddy is looking forward to visiting Big Ears on his day off, but a car accident means he must find alternative transport for his taxi service. While Noddy’s car is in the shop, Mr Honk from Car Town starts up his own taxi service in Toy Town. Noddy and Big Ears must devise a plan! Narrated by Richard Briers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions

results.title: Noddy and Tessie Bear (K)
results.creator_credit: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. Noddy helps Tessie Bear sell her eggs on market day after which they then buy a kite to fly in the strong wind, in a nearby farmer’s paddock. They tie the kite to a milk churn and a basket full of eggs, and the kite lifts the milk and eggs aloft raining milk and eggs on the market before eventually Noddy comes to the rescue. Narrated by Richard Briers.

results.title: Nobody gets out of this band alive
results.brief_description: The Spinning Wheels were an Australian band that played in the mid 60s. They were heavily influenced by early Rolling Stones and took to playing covers by Muddy Waters, Bo Diddley, Chuck Berry and Jimmy Reed. Their version of Muddy Water’s ‘Got my mojo working” became a Top 10 Australian hit. Legendary radio disc jockey Stan ‘The Man’ Rofe said that the band paved the way for rock and roll’s popularity in Melbourne. However, the band failed to release an album until the year 2000. This video shows The Spinning Wheels playing two sets at their album launch at the Melbourne rock and roll venue The Tote. The show was compared by Rofe and features an excellent set by garage rockers The Breadmakers. The sound quality is OK and the picture quality plain as it is only one camera, however, fans of The Spinning Wheels, The Breadmakers, and of early Australian rock and roll would find this video worth checking out. No production details available.

results.title: Nobody's victim
results.creator_credit: Vaughn Ohern, Alan Barker, Ramsgate Films and Self-protection Media for Women
results.brief_description: Based on the book ‘Personal safety and self-defence for women’ by Pat F. Stock. Covers property and life saving precautions, and shows simple defence methods that every woman can use.

results.title: No time to spare
results.brief_description: Gives a detailed demonstration of the Holger-Nielsen method of applying artificial respiration. Shows the technique applied to an adult and a child, pointing out the operator’s position, placement of hands, action and timing.

results.title: No tears for Rachel
results.brief_description: All females, of whatever age, are potential rape victims. Rachel, a young American woman in her twenties, is a rape victim. Rachel tells of her experience, the reaction of her friends to the rape, and her current attitude to the crime. Psychiatrists, lawyers and policemen also discuss the crime of rape and the stigma associated with being raped.

results.title: No such a place
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: In 1952, after only 13 years of operation, the Australian Government closed the Glen Davis Shale Oil Works due to floods, numerous industrial accidents and huge financial losses. The large mining community was forced to leave the valley and the town died. The miners and their families return annually to their beloved town and talk of old times, the curse of Glen Davis and the morning they woke up to find there was “no such a place” Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: No questions asked
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dunkley, Paul Ferguson, Rae Evans and Cygnet Guild Communications
results.brief_description: Dramatic step by step portrayal of how an accident really does happen on a building site. Concentrates on one accident, the events leading up to it, the accident itself, and the immediate aftermath. The procedure to be followed when investigating an accident is clearly shown.

results.title: No other wealth
results.creator_credit: Bert Nicholas, Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: Throughout Victoria, vast areas of land are ravaged by soil erosion, costing the community 6 million dollars each year. The film shows how the Soil Conservation Authority combats erosion by developing methods to stabilize blowing sands with cereal crops; by demonstrating to farmers, methods of contour farming and terracing on sloping country; by reclaiming land ruined by tunnel erosion, and by providing protective cover on reclaimed country.
